desc: The essential Bitcoin reading list: The Bitcoin Standard, 21 Lessons, Mastering Bitcoin, and more.

msgs.text: "The Bitcoin Standard" is a must read for all Bitcoiners. It goes through the history of money throughout mankind, the process of qualitative easing and debasement, and Bitcoin's solution to these problems. Free PDF: https://t.co/BEfe27oxor https://amzn.to/3mx4PCu
I haven't read this one yet, but "The Sovereign Individual" is highly recommended in this space. https://amzn.to/3mBhMv3

"Mastering Bitcoin" by Andreas gets into the more technical side of things. If you're a coder or interested in coding, this one would be good for you. For free: https://github.com/bitcoinbook/bitcoinbook Buy it: https://amzn.to/3wahfUa

I bought "Bitcoin Money: A Tale of Bitville Discovering Good Money" for all my friends with young children. It is a cute (marketed as for all ages) story that details about goods and services being offered by children in a fictional neighborhood called Bitville. It slowly introduces them to the properties of hard money and eventually, Bitcoin makes an appearance! https://amzn.to/2ZIqpeP

"The Internet of Money," also by Andreas, is a book that delves into the "why" of bitcoin: https://amzn.to/2ZHOJgV The talks that this book are based off of can be listened to for free here: https://theinternetofmoney.info/the-talks/

FREE LINK for Inventing Bitcoin: The Technology Behind The First Truly Scarce and Decentralized Money Explained by Yan Pritzker. Some of the best say this is the greatest Bitcoin introduction that is also noob friendly.

The Book Of Satoshi: The Collected Writings of Bitcoin Creator Satoshi Nakamoto 
https://amzn.to/3w7bR42

Haven't read this yet but plan to

Layered Money: From Gold and Dollars to Bitcoin and Central Bank Digital Currencies 
https://amzn.to/2Y56zJF
The Blocksize War can be read for free (Google the book, chapter number you want, and "Bitmex") on Bitmex: https://blog.bitmex.com/the-blocksize-war-chapter-1-first-strike/

Just got my copy of this!
I am planning to read it in the coming few weeks, but I don't want to read it all at once... but slowly to savor each chapter
I'm trying not to spend too much money buying btc books all at once
My other to-reads are things like 7th property, blocksize wars, btc is venice, hard money can't f with, etc.
It's so good! Enjoy

Does anyone know if the Bitcoin Dog (delves into c++ source code of btc) is a good book?
i think i might be taking a C++ course eventually (put more details in offtopic channel)

Yeah I've read it. It's short (40 pages or so) but it's a cute story that guides you into the actual Bitcoin core code. It's not super technical although some of it went over my head. I'd recommend it if you're getting into C++.
I also know the author pretty well from interacting with him a lot on twitter. I can connect you with him if you want,

Inventing Bitcoin for free including audio option
http://Swan.com/freebook
https://twitter.com/jackleepv/status/1561279706342703106?t=Ngl7HQDybJ2Ku6rc9cKfFA&s=19

Not sure that it's exactly a Bitcoin book.
But I really enjoyed The Silver Circle graphic novel, about an underground hard money subculture resisting the Federal Reserve (in an alternate timeline without Bitcoin)
It was written in I think 2013 and set in maybe 2022

I read it just days before becoming a Bitcoiner. It seemed like the real world prophecy of the hard money viral adoption was coming true for BTC but not the metals. An interesting alternative timeline to explore.

It was the last thing I read shortly before becoming Bitcoiner
It's basically a vision of what the world would be if Bitcoin and crypto never happened
Where underground physical mints of bullion are the underground monetary system

Conceived in Liberty 
free download 
https://archive.org/details/ConceivedInLiberty

It is a detailed narrative history of the struggle between liberty and power, as we might expect, but it is more. Rothbard offers a third alternative to the conventional interpretive devices. Against those on the right who see the American Revolution as a "conservative" event, and those on the left who want to invoke it as some sort of proto-socialist uprising, Rothbard views this period as a time of accelerating libertarian radicalism. Through this prism, Rothbard illuminates events as never before.

The volumes were brought out in the 1970s, but the odd timing and uneven distribution prevented any kind of large audience. They were beloved only by a few specialists, and sought after by many, thanks to their outstanding reputation. The Mises Institute is pleased to be the publisher of this integrated book.

This single volume covers the discovery of the Americas and the colonies in the 17th century, the period of "salutary neglect" in the first half of the 18th century, the advance to revolution, from 1760-1775 and the political, military, and ideological history of the revolution and after.
